awd_titl_txt: Language Variation Within and Across Speakers: Special Session at the 2016 CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Language variation is a very prominent phenomenon in society. The growing social and geographical mobility of the world's population had led to an increasing number of bilinguals and non-native speakers in the US, and subsequently, to an increased presence and public awareness of different languages, accents, and registers within communities and the media. In spite of these developments, research on how humans learn, speak, and understand language has been primarily concerned with monolingual speakers of a standard language variety. Language processing models of bilinguals, heritage speakers (in particular, children of immigrants), and second-language learners have been primarily defined as being different from the monolingual native, "invariant" case. This however ignores the fact that speakers who identify as monolingual also need to deal with language variation on a daily basis, and that a majority of the world's population is bilingual. Given the importance and ubiquity of language variation, this phenomenon can therefore no longer be ignored in language processing research. 

Language variation is a challenge for language acquisition and processing models. How do listeners realize that different utterances are different ways of saying the same thing, rather than different things? How do speakers/listeners determine which option is more appropriate or relevant given the context and whom they are talking to? The aim of the special session of the 2016 CUNY conference is to increase awareness regarding language variation in general, and its importance for research on language learning and processing more specifically, by giving an overview of the state-of-the-art research on language variation, particularly in bilinguals. Invited speakers will be asked to address the challenges of language variation for language acquisition and processing, and to provide answers as to how language variation can be taken into account. The ultimate goal is to create a more realistic and representative picture of how the human mind represents, processes and acquires language. This will help provide critical empirical findings relevant for improving language education, techniques to diagnose and treat language impairment, and expand research and processing models to underrepresented groups in the language sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Supported by NSF, the 29th Annual CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing included a special session on Language variation within and across speakers. The conference was held at the Hilton University of Florida Conference Center in Gainesville, FL on March 3-5, 2016.

Intellectual merits:

Language variation is a very prominent phenomenon in society. The growing social and geographical mobility of the world’s population has led to an increasing number of bilinguals and non-native speakers, and subsequently, to an increased presence and public awareness of different languages, accents, and registers within communities and the media. Language variation has also recently been more recognized and cherished as a means of identity, as reflected in a growing number of media outlets in local dialects and minority languages.

In spite of these developments, research on how humans learn, speak, and understand language has been primarily concerned with monolingual speakers of a standard language variety. Language processing models of bilinguals, heritage speakers (in particular, children of immigrants), and second-language learners have been primarily defined as being different from the monolingual native, “invariant" case. This however ignores the fact that also speakers who identify as monolingual need to deal with language variation on a daily basis, and that a majority of the world’s population is bilingual. Given the importance and ubiquity of language variation, this phenomenon deserves more attention in language processing research. However, language variation is a challenge for language acquisition and processing models. How do listeners/readers realize that different utterances are different ways of saying the same thing, rather than different things? How do speakers/listeners determine which option is more appropriate or relevant given the context and whom they are talking to?

The aim of the special session was to increase awareness regarding language variation in general, and its importance for psycholinguistic research more specifically. The special session consisted of presentations by six distinguished scholars, all experts on language variation, who laid out the state-of-the-art of language variation research in their fields. The invited presenters were: Douglas Biber (Northern Arizona University), Hélène Blondeau (University of Florida), Cynthia Clopper (Ohio State University), Paola Dussias (Pennsylvania State University), Maria Polinsky (University of Maryland), and Guillaume Thierry (Bangor University, U.K.). These scholars represented a wide range of linguistic subdisciplines (sociolinguistics, corpus linguistics, psycholinguistics), and covered a variety of linguistic phenomena and methodologies. The invited speakers addressed the following questions (1) What are the major challenges that language variation poses for a language learner (first, second, bilingual) and for language comprehension and production? (2) Do current models of language processing and acquisition deal with variation in an adequate way? If not, how would these models need to be extended, or what are alternative solutions? (3) What insights does your own research on language variation provide that can benefit psycholinguistic research in general? (4) What are the remaining major challenges related to language variation from a research point of view?  

In addition to the invited talks, poster and paper presentations on the topic of language variation were solicited from the wider psycholinguistic community. Accepted submissions on the special topic (9 out of 28 accepted talks, and 43 of the 179 presented posters) received special attention in the conference program.

Broader Impacts:

Educational Impact: From its inception, the CUNY conference has been committed to attracting graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, encouraging them to attend and participate in the proceedings. To encourage participation of students and young scholars (1) travel support was provided for 30 student participant; (2) for the first time, one session was devoted to 15-minute "flash talks" to provide a less intimidating forum for young scholars to present their work; (3) the Jerrold J. Katz Young Scholar Award was issued; this is a $500 award, donated by regular conference attendees, given annually to the best paper or poster presented at the conference by an individual within three years of receiving the PhD and not yet tenured; (4) local students assisted with the organization, and were encouraged to attend the conference presentations.

Impact on the Scientific Community: The 2016 special session was specifically designed to appeal to the widest possible spectrum of conference attendees. The conference drew 304 registered attendees from four continents, and from a wide range of disciplines (linguistics, cognitive science, neuroscience, foreign languages, education, communication disorders, computer science). Furthermore, the CUNY conference encourages cross-disciplinary interaction by having plenary rather than parallel sessions. To encourage dissemination of the findings in research and educational settings, the program and abstracts remain freely downloadable from the conference website (cuny2016.lin.ufl.edu).
